docs.lead_paragraph: ''This is a good bill that will help every Medicare beneficiary,'' wrote Tom Scully, the Medicare administrator, in a letter to The New York Times defending the prescription drug bill. That's flatly untrue. (Are you surprised?) As the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities points out, the bill will force millions of beneficiaries to pay more for drugs, thanks to a provision that cuts off supplemental aid from Medicaid. Poorer recipients may find previously affordable drugs moving out of reach. That's only one of a number of anti-retiree measures tucked away in the bill. It contains several Trojan horse provisions that are clearly intended to undermine Medicare over time -- it will allow private insurers to cherry-pick healthy clients in selected cities, and it will heavily subsidize private plans competing with traditional Medicare. Meanwhile, the bill prohibits Medicare from using its bargaining power to cut drug prices; drug company stocks have soared since the bill's details became public.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column deplores what he sees as number of anti-retiree measures tucked away away in prescription drug bill, but notes bill has good chance of passing, thanks to an endorsement from AARP, retiree advocacy orgn; questions why AARP did not take its time in considering bill, which has huge implications for future of Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: ''This is a good bill that will help every Medicare beneficiary,'' wrote Tom Scully, the Medicare administrator, in a letter to The New York Times defending the prescription drug bill. That's flatly untrue. (Are you surprised?) As the Center on...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tucked into this week's announcement of a merger between two insurance companies, the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation and the St. Paul Companies, was the news that the consolidated company will move its headquarters to Minnesota, removing another chess piece from Hartford's already diminished board. Within two years, the city once known as the insurance capital of the world will be the home office of just two major insurance corporations. ''The insurance capital? I don't even think it's an insurance capital anymore,'' said Richard L. Huber, chief executive of Aetna from 1997 to 2000 and now a private investor with homes in Hartford and Manhattan.

headline.main: Latest Merger Makes It Clearer Than Ever: Hartford Is No Longer the Insurance Capital

docs.abstract: Exodus of insurance companies from Hartford continues as Travelers Property Casuality Corp and St Paul Cos merge and announce consolidation of operations outside Connecticut; Phoenix Cos and Hartford Financial Services Group are only major insurance corporations left in city; struggling city expects to lose money for cultural and charity organizations as well as civic leaders; photo; chart with timeline on Hartford's vanishing insurance companies (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to discredit the AARP's endorsement of the Medicare bill now before Congress, opponents of the bill are pointing to what they say are the group's financial stakes in the legislation. John Rector, a senior vice president of the National Community Pharmacists Association, a trade group for independent drugstores, said yesterday that AARP, the biggest advocacy group for the elderly, had ''a well-documented, inherent conflict of interest based on income from health insurance products sold to AARP members.''

headline.main: Opponents of Medicare Bill Say AARP Has Conflicts

docs.abstract: Opponents of Medicare bill before Congress, seeking to discredit AARP's endorsement of bill, are pointing to what they say are group's financial stakes in legislation; National Community Pharmacists Association senior vice president John Rector says AARP has well-documented, inherent conflict of interest based on income from health insurance products sold to AARP members; AARP says its commercial interests are likely to be damaged, not helped, by passage of bill, which would add prescription drug benefit to Medicare in 2006 and promote competition with Medicare by private health plans; retail pharmacies object to many provisions of bill; consumer advocacy group Public Citizen says AARP would stand to gain many millions of dollars in new income under Republican Medicare bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Attacks in Istanbul Hit British Sites, Killing 27 Two explosions wrecked the British Consulate and a British bank in Istanbul, killing at least 27 people and wounding 450. An anonymous caller to the Anatolian news agency claimed the attack was a joint effort of Al Qaeda and a Turkish terror group. The same groups also claimed responsibility for the bombings of two Istanbul synagogues. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate negotiators finished work on a far-reaching overhaul of Medicare on Thursday, expanding benefits to build support for the legislation to the very end. Democrats shut out of the negotiations denounced the process as illegitimate and said the measure would leave millions of elderly people worse off. The bill, tentatively scheduled for a vote on the House floor on Friday, offers outpatient drug coverage to 40 million elderly and disabled people. The Senate is expected to begin debate on the legislation on Saturday, and Republican strategists in both chambers said they were optimistic that the huge bill would be passed before Congress adjourns for Thanksgiving.

headline.main: Congress Completes Details of Medicare Bill

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore the controversial topic of same-sex marriages in a fishbowl discussion. They then write balanced news articles based on interviews exploring people's opinions on laws that define marriage.

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric said yesterday that it expected to return to profit growth of more than 10 percent in 2005 after no or modest growth next year, as it splits off insurance assets to focus on faster-growing health care technology and entertainment media. G.E. said on Tuesday that it intended to split off most of its mortgage and life insurance operations through an initial offering. G.E. last posted a profit increase of more than 10 percent in 2001. Its chairman, Jeffrey R. Immelt, said reduced shipments of gas turbines and lower pension income would continue to drag on earnings next year. In 2005, he said, he expects profit to rise by up to 15 percent as G.E. moves into faster-growth businesses and sheds underperforming assets. G.E. also said it planned to increase its quarterly dividend by 5 percent, to 20 cents a share.

headline.main: G.E. PROJECTS UPWARD OF 10% GROWTH RATE IN 2005

docs.abstract: General Electric expects to return to profit growth of more than 10 percent in 2005 after no or modest growth next year (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Members of the Chicago Teachers Union approved a four-year contract by a slim majority, avoiding what could have been the first strike in 16 years. The contract calls for an annual raise of 4 percent and improved health care benefits. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Teachers' Contract Avoids Strike
